Sample Criteria Extension for Multinomial Regression

Source: R/pmsamplesize.r
pmsamplesize.Rd

Calculate sample criteria extended for multinominal regression.

Usage

pmsamplesize(
  Q,
  k,
  p,
  adjust = FALSE,
  r2_cs_app = NULL,
  r2_cs_adj = NULL,
  shrinkage = 0.9,
  r2_nagelkerke = 0.15,
  auc = NULL,
  prev = NULL,
  sigma = 0.05,
  margin_error = 0.05
)

Arguments

Q

An integer. The number of candidate predictors. See Details

k

An integer. The number of levels in response variable

p

A numeric vector. Outcome proportion(s) or event observations

adjust

A logical. Should adjusted R-square value be used? Default to FALSE

r2_cs_app

A numeric vector. The apparent Cox-Snell \(R^2\)

r2_cs_adj

A numeric vector. The optimism-adjusted Cox-Snell \(R^2\)

shrinkage

A pre-defined shrinkage factor. Default to 0.9

r2_nagelkerke

An adjustment for Cox-Snell \(R^2\). Default to 0.15.

auc

A numeric vector. Pairwise C statistics

prev

A numeric vector. Outcome proportions in categories relative to reference

sigma

A double. Tolerate rate between adjusted \(R^2\) and apparent \(R^2\). Default to 0.05

margin_error

A double. A divergence for margin error specified by Chi-square distribution's confidence level. Default to 0.05

Value

A pmsample class object

  • final: A single row data frame representing the selected criterion for the minimum sample size for developing a new model

  • criteria: A data frame containing all the sample sizes based on three criteria. Divergences in sample sizes due to number rounding

  • sigma: A single numeric representing the tolerate rate between adjusted \(R^2\) and apparent \(R^2\)

  • margin_error: A divergence for margin error specified by Chi-square distribution's confidence level

Details

The pmsample objects created by pmsamplesize can represent the minimum sample size needed for developing a new model based on the current studies.

pmsamplesize function adapts the amount of information based on the type of model. A certain parameters need pre-specifying for calculation:

  • The number of candidate predicators Q, usually obtained using the fractional polynomial method and it is not addressed by this package.

  • The number of levels in response variable k, typically for a binary model k = 2, for multinomial models k > 2. One of the argument between k or p, the outcome proportions or the observation counts of the events, must be specified. In the case of a missing k, it will then defined by the length of p.

  • The order of p matters for calculation: for a binary model, the second value in the vector is perceived as 'outcome proportion' or 'outcome events'.

  • Pairwise C-statistics auc for simulation. The process requires estimates of the pairwise outcome proportions \(\phi_{k,r}\) of category k relative to the reference category r, prev. If not supplied, they will be derived from p.

References

Examples

# when only C statistics is reported in a binary model
set.seed(1234)
pmsamplesize(Q = 30, k = 2, r2_nagelkerke = 0.15, auc = 0.81, prev = 0.77)
#> Warning: Inadequate information to calculate sample size for criterion 2
#> NB: Assuming 0.05 acceptable difference in apparent & adjusted R-squared
#> NB: Assuming 0.05 margin of error in estimation of intercept
#> NB: Events per Predictor Parameter assumes prevalance 0.77 
#>            sample_size shrinkage parameter CS_Rsq Max_Rsq Nag_Rsq   EPP
#> Criteria 1        1130       0.9        30   0.21      NA    0.15 29.00
#> Criteria 3         273       0.9        30   0.21      NA    0.15  7.01
#> Final             1130       0.9        30   0.21      NA    0.15 29.00
#> Minimum sample size required for new model development based on user inputs = 1130,
#>  with 870 events (assuming an outcome prevalence = 0.77) and an EPP = 29
